title: Sione Mata'utia
text:
Sione Mata'utia-Leifi (pronounced ma-ta-oo-tee-a) (born 25 June 1996) is a professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who plays as a and forward for <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St Helens</a> in the <a href="Betfred%20Super%20League">Betfred Super League</a>. He has represented both <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia</a> and <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoa</a> at international level.
He previously played for the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>, as well as the <a href="Prime%20Minister%27s%20XIII">Prime Minister's XIII</a> and <a href="NRL%20All%20Stars%20team">World All Stars</a> at representative level. Mata'utia played as and on the earlier in his career, before moving into the forwards.
Background.
Mata'utia was born in <a href="Liverpool%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Liverpool, New South Wales</a>, Australia. He is of <a href="Samoans">Samoan</a> descent and moved to <a href="Newcastle%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Newcastle, New South Wales</a> when he was 5 years old.
He played his junior football for the <a href="Raymond%20Terrace%20Magpies">Raymond Terrace Magpies</a> and <a href="South%20Newcastle%20Lions">South Newcastle Lions</a> in the <a href="Newcastle%20Rugby%20League">Newcastle Rugby League</a>, before being signed by the <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle Knights</a>.
Mata'utia is the younger brother of former Knights players <a href="Peter%20Mata%27utia">Peter Mata'utia</a>, <a href="Chanel%20Mata%27utia">Chanel Mata'utia</a> and <a href="Pat%20Mata%27utia">Pat Mata'utia</a>.
Playing career.
Early career.
In 2013 and 2014, Mata'utia played for Newcastle's <a href="National%20Youth%20Competition%20%28rugby%20league%29">NYC</a> team. On 16 October 2013, he extended his contract with the Knights from the end of 2014 to the end of 2015. On 12 June 2013, he won the <a href="Brian%20Carlson">Brian Carlson Club</a>-<a href="Andrew%20Johns">Andrew Johns</a> Medal as Newcastle's best under-17 player. In September and November 2013, he captained the <a href="Australian%20Schoolboys%20rugby%20league%20team">Australian Schoolboys</a>.
2014.
On 3 May, Mata'utia played for the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales</a> Under-20s team against the <a href="Queensland%20rugby%20league%20team">Queensland</a> Under-20s team, playing at centre and scoring a try in New South Wales' 30-8 win at <a href="Penrith%20Stadium">Penrith Stadium</a>.
In round 20 of the <a href="2014%20NRL%20season">2014 NRL season</a>, he made his <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> debut for Newcastle against the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a> at fullback, alongside his brother <a href="Chanel%20Mata%27utia">Chanel Mata'utia</a> who also debuted for the Knights in the same game. This was the first time since Round 1 of the <a href="1942%20NSWRFL%20season">1942 NSWRFL season</a>, that two brothers had debuted in the same game together, <a href="Bill%20McRitchie">Bill</a> and <a href="Doug%20McRitchie">Doug McRitchie</a> debuting for the <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George Dragons</a> on that day. In round 23 against the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> at <a href="Hunter%20Stadium">Hunter Stadium</a>, he scored his first NRL career try in a three try effort for Newcastle during their 28-22 win. He finished off his debut year in the NRL having played in seven matches and scoring seven tries for Newcastle in the 2014 season. On 2 September, he was named at centre in the 2014 NYC Team of the Year.
On 8 September 2014, he was named in the <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoa</a> train-on squad for the <a href="2014%20Rugby%20League%20Four%20Nations">2014 Four Nations</a>, later being also named in the <a href="Junior%20Kangaroos">Junior Kangaroos</a> train-on squad. On 12 October 2014, he played for the <a href="Prime%20Minister%27s%20XIII">Prime Minister's XIII</a> against <a href="Papua%20New%20Guinea%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Papua New Guinea</a>. On 14 October 2014, he was named in the <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australian</a> 2014 Four Nations squad. He became Australia's youngest ever Test player when he played against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a>, aged 18 years and 129 days, eclipsing <a href="Israel%20Folau">Israel Folau</a>'s seven-year-old record by 65 days. He played in 3 matches for Australia including playing on the wing and scoring a try in the Kangaroos' 22-18 loss to <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> at <a href="Westpac%20Stadium">Westpac Stadium</a>.
Late in September 2014, he signed a letter of intent to join the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a> on a four-year contract starting in 2016, along with his brothers Chanel and Pat. However, the NRL's rules didn't allow Canterbury to register the contracts until 30 June 2015, leaving the option of staying at Newcastle open for the Mata'utias.
2015.
On 31 January and 1 February, Mata'utia played for Newcastle in the <a href="2015%20NRL%20Auckland%20Nines">2015 NRL Auckland Nines</a>. On 19 March, he re-signed with Newcastle on a three-year contract, along with his brothers Chanel and Pat. He finished off the <a href="2015%20NRL%20season">2015 season</a> having played in 22 matches and scoring 3 tries as the club finished last.
2016.
In February, Mata'utia played for Newcastle in the <a href="2016%20NRL%20Auckland%20Nines">2016 NRL Auckland Nines</a>. In round 17 against the <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra Raiders</a>, he switched from the centres to second-row in Newcastle's 21-25 golden-point extra time loss at <a href="Canberra%20Stadium">Canberra Stadium</a>. This would later prove to be a permanent move for the rest of the season. He finished the <a href="2016%20NRL%20season">2016 season</a> having played in 16 matches and scoring 4 tries.
2017.
In round 8 of the <a href="2017%20NRL%20season">2017 season</a>, Mata'utia captained Newcastle for the first time in their loss to <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland</a>. He played a total of 22 games for Newcastle in the <a href="2017%20NRL%20season">2017 NRL season</a> as the club finished last for a third straight year.
2018.
In June, Mata'utia re-signed with Newcastle on a three-year contract until the end of 2021.
2019.
Mata'utia played 22 games and scored five tries for Newcastle in the <a href="2019%20NRL%20season">2019 NRL season</a> as the club finished 11th on the table.
2020.
Mata'utia had an interrupted 2020 season due to injury, only playing in 12 matches for Newcastle. After 124 games for the Knights, he was released from the final year of his contract in November to take up a three-year contract with <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> club <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St Helens R.F.C.</a> starting in 2021.
2021.
In round 1 of the 2021 Super League season, he made his debut for St. Helens in their 29-6 victory over <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a>.
On 14 July, Mata'utia was suspended for two matches and missed St. Helens Challenge Cup final victory over <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a>.
On 9 October, he played for St. Helens in their <a href="2021%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">2021 Super League Grand Final</a> victory over <a href="Catalans%20Dragons">Catalans Dragons</a>.
